comments.commentBody: Isn't the Prime Meridian in Greenwich, not London?
I think a better clue than "Blackbirds" at 42D is "Reagle and others".

I think we might consider the following formulæ:
a moiety + x = a quorum
two moieties = a plenum
a plenum + x = a nimiety
vulgarly known a a glut (not to be confused with a plethora)
O dearth, where is thy sting?

Martin, I like your Fugeddaboudit primer, but I'm gonna question "go know" being Brooklynese. Jewish New Yorkese, maybe. I bet it's translated straight from Yiddish. (I'm sure you'll tell me!)

KS, just come out and call me a twit, why don't you? Ouch. Guilty.

Great puzzle.

Yes, revolution does not always imply a turn for the better. I can't imagine not tooting my idiosyncratic vuvuzela on the fourth of July to celebrate 234 years of independence. We are not anymore under a prudish and restrictive social mindset! Hooray! Otherwise, it looks like Germany had a NIMIETY of goals against Argentina today.

EminHen are up to their usual high standard.
I had thought that the answers to
the F. clue (Collection with nothing in it (2 wds.)) would be too mathematical for most (or did we all remember our New Math?), while the the J. clue ( Inuit territory made official in 1999) would be for Canadians only. I was apparently wrong as nobody complained. What an erudite lot we apparently are!

I liked the subtle link of this Acrostic to July 4th made in the EminHen Notes.

I was going to call the theme clues "elisions," but Patrick's "twords" is a much better choice. The answers to the theme clues looked perfectly normal, even though they had been forced into a twordsy union.

We can steal a phrase from the art world "trompe l'oeil" (trick of the eye) as an accurate descriptor of the puzzles "trick".

For my money, this was a perfect Sunday crossword. Thank you, Patrick, Tony and Will.

@JolleyGood, I also briefly thought rebus, although the puzzle theme does appear in Across Lite.  Didn't ruin the challenge for me, but did validate the first theme fill I got, which was PERSONALITYPE.   Yup, tried all the corners going clockwise until I got traction in the SW.  This one gave me over an hour of entertainment!  At least, that's how I like to look at my snail-like progress through the grid.  Looking for something to set off fireworks (and not finding anything), I do notice I have  MAINTED at 107A.  Hmmm...  That a word?

Senate stars = ASTRA? There are other Senates besides the one in ancient Rome, you know.

I would have gone for TURN INTO.

I got NOP from the crosses, but I'm not happy with the clue.

CAESURA was a new word and pretty arcane, but I'll have to let it pass. Although it would have been very helpful for 41A( _LS_), 44A (_IM) & 50A (_ENA_ _T).

I was able to work out the rest.

-- jpgaskell

The N.F. whose complaint about waiting 45 minutes to see the doctor, there is bad news ahead. With 45 million more patients and fewer docs to see them under the new health care plan, patient waits will inevitibly be even longer once the plan kicks in mid decade.
All day waits will not be uncomon with htose unseen being told to come back tomorrow. Switching to a different doctor will note be better,the patient waits will be the same for all.
Marshall Wolf

I'm a former New Yorker - disgusted with how "things" are going in the US [having never seen such antics as the health care reform debate or the shenanigans of tea parties] and moved to Ontario. For me it's space. $2,000 a month more for 1000 additional square feet - that can be used every day, regardless of weather...That's it. Space.

Comparing a NYC 2-bedroom to a 3 or 4 BR suburban house is one thing.  If your family is big enough, as mine is, to require at least three bedrooms, the game is over.  The jump in price from 2 to 3 BR in any decent NYC neighborhood is at least $300k.   And the suburban house remains the same price as examined in the article.  End of story once you have 3+ kids.  So here we are, and it's okay.  I think the kids play a lot more team sports than they would have in the city, which I regard as a plus, and the schools are great.  There's no time- and emotion- draining hardball every few years to get them into some Lab school or some good high school.

I opened a Smarty Pig account more than a year ago. In May 2010 I had to move money out of SP because of their $50K limit. The whole SP system is a big pain--but it's the highest rate around for the least trouble. Telephone customer service is very good. Once everything was set up, a time consuming and rather confusing process, I've really had no complaints. I believe SP has added a feature not available earlier--redeeming only part of a goal. This makes it more convenient than previously.

BTW once your goal is met, SP does not continue to automatically withdraw from checking acct. So, just set your goal low, and you'll meet it immediately when you transfer funds from lower interest accts.

Move to Philadelphia if you want to live afordably in a major  east coast city. My three story 1895 house with many original details renovated room by room over the past 16 years, located on a garden-filled, family friendly block, would cost 1-2 million dollars in Brooklyn, maybe 6 million dollars in San Francisco, but I could probably sell it for at best $400,000 here.  The real estate and life style available in this city are very accessible.  There is the public/private school issue, but there are a few places in the city with excellent public schools, and with lower cost of living, private schools are more affordable.

High Rise or House with Yard?

I thought it would be fun to compare the housing costs here in Minneapolis, where I live, to the examples given in your story. It turned out to be more interesting than I expected.

I grew up in Manhattan, in Washington Heights, but I’ve spent most of my life living in Minneapolis. We raised two daughters in our house in Minneapolis and now it’s just us - two 78 year old senior citizens living in a 2000 square foot house. It’s a nice house, built in 1922 in a very nice neighborhood of well kept homes. A major feature of our neighborhood is a large, very popular city lake at the end of our block. The main change to our neighborhood over the past 40 years has been the replacement of our huge elm trees with young maple trees. There has also been a general upgrade of almost all of the houses. As I said, this is a nice neighborhood, very attractive to families. The best elementary, Jr. high and high schools in Minneapolis just happen to be in our district. A recent change is what we call “turnover”: couples with small children replacing old folks like us. It happened when we moved in, it’s happening now. We are very pleased; it’s fun to hear children again. The assessed value of the houses in our neighborhood runs between $600,000 and $800,000, with ours right in the middle. Real estate taxes run from $5000 to $10,000 per year. Minnesota State income taxes average about 60 to 70 per cent of federal taxes. This is not an inexpensive state to live in. But it’s a very nice place to live, and it’s our willingness to pay taxes that makes it so. In terms of quality of life, neither NJ nor Brooklyn comes anywhere close.

It was clear as I looked at the numbers that the cost of housing in NJ was higher, while the cost of living in the high rise in Brooklyn was lower. We were right in the middle. Using the old fashioned, but now fully vindicated, formula that housing should consume 30 to 40 per cent of income put us right in the $175,000 per year income class. But I have never even dreamt of earning as much as $175,000 dollars per year. What’s going on here? I know we live as well as any of our new neighbors.

A look at the numbers and all becomes clear. The numbers assume a family with children buying a home with a 20% down payment and a 30 year 5% loan. Such a family has a mortgage and social security taxes to pay, a need for life insurance and has the costs of raising children. They also need to set aside some earnings as savings. My budget includes none of these. We have no earned income, so no SS; we have no need for life insurance, no need for savings (actually, a third of our income comes from savings) and no children to raise. But the big number is that we own our home; no mortgage expense.

Try it. Just eliminating mortgage expense dramatically changes the picture. The fact is, the ratios are real. Eliminating mortgage expense implies reductions in other expenses as well.

These numbers are real. We actually spend around $70,000 a year to live; our new neighbors across the street with their two cute children really need $175,000 to live as well as we do. These are the numbers that make retirement for the middle class possible. As we are, others will be – including that nice family across the street. There is reason for hope.

Charlie Turpin
Minneapolis MN

Having made the decision to leave our apartment for the suburbs when little ones came along, I can say the cost arguments in this article are not that simple. If you live in the outer boroughs and not near mass transit or shopping (easy in many Queens and Staten Island neighborhoods) you are probably buying a car anyway. Speaking from experience,child care/pre-school etc. costs much more in the city than in the suburbs. In many neighborhoods the park is an asphalt paved lot (and in the case of my old Queens school it is partially covered with trailers). I also found food prices to be higher in the city, though that is in part due to being unable to buy in bulk. Finally, once little ones showed up, we really stopped caring about bars and great restaurants, aside from child friendly ones, and started caring about a washer and dryer (or swing set) that we didn't have to take an elevator to and could use whenever we wanted. I'm not even going to start on the schools.

There are trades every day and life and my wife practically took me screaming and kicking from our apartment. But, having grown up in a 2 bedroom apartment with the dining room converted to a third bedroom for my sister, and large apartments not really available for the middle class, I knew I didn't feel like repeating that part of my life. By the way, there are four other boroughs other than Manhattan. I grew up in Queens, a 10 min bus ride and a 45 minute subway ride to midtown -- or about the same as my NJ Transit bus ride is now. The city and its attractions are about as close as they were when I was a child -- except my children have a yard and go to much better schools.

I currently owe $50K on my federal student loans for an education I would not trade for the world from my large state research institution, the University of Washington, as well as a master's from Syrcause University.  I paid MY OWN WAY through it all...no help from parents (eight kids in my family).  I worked my tail off year round, was the grateful recipient of Pell Grants, more scholarships than I can count, and a University Fellowship at Syracuse.  (Also won a Fulbright to the United Kingdom funded generously by the U.S. government, for which I am eternally grateful.)  With so many jobs, grants, scholarships, and fellowships, one might express surprise at my high debt.  Living is expensive, and with zero family help, loans allowed me to survive.  I nabbed a tenure track position as a college professor at a large state research university in the midwest.  My starting salary in 1999 was $39,000/year.  Loan repayments choked me nearly to death.  I was able to defer them for seven years (while I struggled, in general, to pay my other bills) BUT THE 7% INTEREST CONTINUED TO ACCRUE.  Before I knew it, I owed ten thousand additional dollars in interest.  Currently, I am in good standing but for every $434 I pay each month only $82 goes to the prinicipal.  The rest just keeps my head above water in interest payments.  I am NOT interested in visiting bankruptcy court.  There must be a happy medium.  I have consolidated my loans once to a rate of 7%--and am barred from doing so again.  This is akin to being blocked from refinancing one's house when the interest rates tumble.  I have worked through my rage at the system, kept my head above water, and just keep plugging on.  I'm 45 now and dearly wish I could sock what I am paying in student loans away into retirement.  I look forward to the day I can get Nelnet and their stinking, harassing phone calls out of my life.

Again, well done for getting BP to consult before burning your turtles.
AUSTRALIA is a poor man's land if you are a sea turtle. In Australia there is a black market meat trade for the meat and eggs of endangered turtles. Meat and eggs are flown around Queensland on a daily basis and NOBODY bats an eyelid.
It is illegal, yer our federal government doesn't care, our environment minister (Peter Garrett) doesn't care. The airport officials know about it and watch the crates full of meat and eggs pass by. Can you believe this? In Australia?!
I reckon I'd rather be a turtle in the oil spill than a turtle in Australia.

Per Wikipedia under "Yiddish words used by English-speaking Jews":

geh vays – literally "go know," as in "go figure." ("Last week she said she hated his guts and now she's engaged to him. Geh vays.")

I liked the puzzle,

-- jpgaskell

Obama is doing a great job of accomplishing the objectives stated in the letter already.
People who are poor and unemployed don't consume near as much. Just relax and check the numbers there is no recovery of any sort. Enjoy the ride and start your own communal organic garden on your own non corporate owned piece of gang controlled waste land.

while this may be an immediate victory for clean air, I see it as another illustration of the paradox of renewable energy here in CA - right now one of the top enviro bills in the legislature is to increase the amount of electricity that comes from renewable sources - the pols try to outdo each other in who can force utilities to produce the greatest amount of renewable energy while the regulators make it more difficult to do so - I'm actually more sympathetic to the latter though.

Sol In The Family - The Bunkers enter a hilarious new era as Gloria and Mike divorce and Gloria announces plans to convert to Judaism to please a suitor from the local synagogue.

12 - Under the crushing pressure of the federal deficit, Jack Bauer is forced to accelerate a season of explosive action into a half day.

The Falsettos - a tough, new branch of The Mob takes over the turf of established gangland empires through kidnapping and mutilation.

The Bassos

Gossip Girl's Chuck Bass begins his own opera-tinged crime family. In Manhattan rather than Jersey, of course.

"Lavigne and Surly" -- A Canadian pop star and Russell Crowe share misadventures in a brewery.

"Is Thee A House In This Doctor?" -- Physicians diagnose complex maladies from a list of odd symptoms.

"The Tweet Life on Deck" -- Teens descibe a sea cruise in terse messages.

Red Like Me:

A ring of eleven or so Russo-Soviet spies killed by the Cold War are left in America to reap the souls of remaining espionage agents... until they are discovered.
